title: Schedule
text:
Assignments
Below are assignment due dates for the semester. You can find details and assignment instructions in the relevant week on the schedule.

Homework
Homework will be due by Sunday at 11:59pm. You will have at least 11/12 days to complete each homework assignment.


Labs
Labs will be due on Fridays at 11:59pm. You will start the lab during your scheduled lab section.


Exams
There will be two exams on the dates TBD.

title: Association and Causation
section: GDP Per Capita and Share of Protestants
text: GDP Per Capita and Share of Protestants

title: Association and Causation
section: Literacy Per Capita and Share of Protestants
text: Literacy Per Capita and Share of Protestants

title: Association and Causation
text:
450 counties
Distance from Martin Luther’s birthplace: Wittenberg (Germany) place of Protestant Reformation

The result: the closer counties were to the center of the Protestant movement, the higher their average incomes were—and the higher their literacy rates too. And after controlling for literacy rates, distance from Wittenberg no longer predicted higher income. To the extent that living near the origin of the Protestant Reformation raised people’s incomes, it was entirely attributable to gains in the ability to read and write.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text: This course provides an introduction to machine learning and related methods for big data from an economics perspective. Students will learn modern estimation methods for high-dimensional data, with a focus on causal inference and prediction problems in economics, business, and related fields. Through programming assignments and a final empirical project, students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world data.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text: This course provides an introduction to machine learning and related methods for big data from an economics perspective. Students will learn modern estimation methods for high-dimensional data, with a focus on causal inference and prediction problems in economics, business, and related fields. Through programming assignments and a final empirical project, students will apply machine learning techniques to real-world data.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Learning Outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should be able to:

Apply machine learning methods to estimate causal effects in experimental and observational settings.
Solve prediction problems in economics using machine learning techniques.
Understand the uses, strengths, and limitations of machine learning for answering economic questions.
Implement machine learning algorithms using Python/R.
Analyze and interpret economic data using machine learning methods.
Conduct an empirical research project utilizing machine learning techniques.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Course Structure and Topics

Week 1-2: Introduction to Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics

Overview of big data and machine learning.
Key differences between traditional econometric techniques and machine learning methods.
Readings: Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 1 from Business Data Science




Big Data




Week 3-4: Supervised Learning and Regression

Overview of supervised learning and its relevance to economic data.
Lab: Implementing regression methods using Python/R.
Readings: Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 3; Gareth et al. (2017), Chapter 3, 6 from An Introduction to Statistical Learning



Week 5-6: Classification and Decision Trees

Decision trees, random forests.
Lab: Decision trees and random forests in Python/R.
Readings: Gareth et al. (2017), Chapter 4, 8



Week 7-8: Causal Inference Using Machine Learning

Randomized control trials vs observational data.
Readings: Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 4 from Business Data Science; Angrist & Pischke (2014) Chapter 2 from Mastering ’Metrics



Week 9-10: Unsupervised Learning

Overview of unsupervised learning: PCA and K-means clustering.
Lab: PCA and clustering in Python/R.
Readings: Gareth et al. (2017), Chapter 10



Week 11-12: Model Evaluation and Cross-Validation

Methods for model evaluation, cross-validation.
Lab: Cross-validation and model selection in Python/R.
Readings: Gareth et al. (2017), Chapter 5



Week 13-14: Big Data and Machine Learning in Economics

Case studies in business and economics.
Readings: Taddy, M. (2019), Chapter 5



Week 15: Advanced Topics and Review

Ensemble methods: boosting and bagging.
Lab: Implementing ensemble methods using Python/R.
Readings: Gareth et al. (2017), Chapter 8



Week 16: Empirical Project Presentations

Students present their final empirical projects applying machine learning to a real-world dataset.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Assessment:

Assignments (40%): Regular programming assignments.
Midterm Exam (20%).
Final Project (40%): Empirical project applying course concepts to data.

title: Machine Learning and Big Data in Economics
text:
Optional Textbooks:

Taddy, M. (2019) Business Data Science: Combining Machine Learning and Economics to Optimize Business Decisions.
ISL Gareth, J.; Witten, D.; Hastie, T.; and Tibshirani, R. (2023) An Introduction to Statistical Learning , 2nd Edition. Springer.
Angrist, J. & Pischke, J. (2014) Mastering ’Metrics: The Path from Cause to Effect.

title: The Taxonomy of Data

claims made using data.

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text:
Data defined

Data:

An item of (chiefly numerical) information, esp. one obtained by scientific work, a number of which are typically collected together for reference, analysis, or calculation.



From latin datum: that which is given.
Facts.


Variable:
A characteristic of an object / unit that can be measured / recorded.


Observations: the collection of objects / units that are being measured / recorded.

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text: Draw data Taxonomy on Board

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text:
Types of Variables
Numerical:

Variables that take numbers as values that are sensible to add, subtract, etc.


Categorical:
Variables that take categories as values (called levels).


Continuous:
A numerical variable that takes values on an interval of the real number line.


Discrete:
A numerical variable that takes values that have jumps between them (i.e. an ordered countable set).


Ordinal:
A categorical variable with levels that have a natural ordering.


Nominal:
A categorical variable with levels with no ordering.

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text:
Observing Penguins

Palmer Station, Antarctica
Size measurements for adult foraging penguins near Palmer Station, Antarctica, K. Gorman 2020.

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text:

Beak Length and Beak Depth

These are continuous variables.

title: The Taxonomy of Data
text:
Variable: Species

Species

This is a nominal variable.

A data frame is an array that associates the observations (downs the rows) with the variables measured on each observation (across the columns). Each cell storse a value observed for a variable on an observation.

Unit of observation:
The type of the object on which the variables are observed.

Here: an adult foraging penguin near Palmer Station, Antarctica
